clusters.title: BBC apologises to Trump over documentary, rejects defamation claim
clusters.neutral_headline: BBC Apologizes to Trump, Rejects Defamation Claim
bullet_summary: In a letter, BBC said it had no plans to rebroadcast the documentary that was the basis of Trump's defamation claim
The BBC said on Thursday its chairman had apologised to US President Donald Trump for a misleading edit of one of his speeches, but denied it amounted to defamation
The broadcaster also said it was probing a possible second instance of a Trump speech edited in a misleading way
President Donald Trump said he has an obligation to proceed with his threatened $1 billion lawsuit against the BBC for editing a speech he made on Jan

items.title: BBC apologises to Trump over documentary, rejects defamation claim
items.standfirst: In a letter, BBC said it had no plans to rebroadcast the documentary that was the basis of Trump's defamation claim.
items.content: In a letter, BBC said it had no plans to rebroadcast the documentary that was the basis of Trump's defamation claim.

items.title: BBC apologises to Trump over edited speech but rejects compensation claim
items.standfirst: ‘We strongly disagree there is a basis for a defamation claim’, reads statement expressing ‘sincere regrets’ over Panorama episodeThe BBC has apologised to Donald Trump over the editing of a Panorama documentary that led to the resignation of its director general, Tim Davie, and the BBC News chief, Deborah Turness.However, the corporation has rejected his demands for compensation, after lawyers for Trump threatened to sue for $1bn (£760m) in damages unless the BBC issued a retraction, apologised and settled with him. Continue reading...
items.content: ‘We strongly disagree there is a basis for a defamation claim’, reads statement expressing ‘sincere regrets’ over Panorama episodeThe BBC has apologised to Donald Trump over the editing of a Panorama documentary that led to the resignation of its director general, Tim Davie, and the BBC News chief, Deborah Turness.However, the corporation has rejected his demands for compensation, after lawyers for Trump threatened to sue for $1bn (£760m) in damages unless the BBC issued a retraction, apologised and settled with him. Continue reading...

items.title: BBC apologises to Trump over film edit but rejects defamation claim
items.standfirst: The BBC said on Thursday its chairman had apologised to US President Donald Trump for a misleading edit of one of his speeches, but denied it amounted to defamation. The broadcaster also said it was probing a possible second instance of a Trump speech edited in a misleading way.
items.content: The BBC said on Thursday its chairman had apologised to US President Donald Trump for a misleading edit of one of his speeches, but denied it amounted to defamation. The broadcaster also said it was probing a possible second instance of a Trump speech edited in a misleading way.

ai_summary: The BBC apologized to Donald Trump for an edited speech segment in a documentary.

Trump's lawyers threatened to sue the BBC for $1 billion in damages.
The BBC is also investigating a possible second misleading edit of a speech.
The BBC stated there was no basis for Trump's defamation claim.

clusters.title: What we learned from newly released Jeffrey Epstein emails
clusters.neutral_headline: New Epstein Emails Released, Mention Trump
bullet_summary: Democrats said the emails, including one in which Epstein said Trump spent hours at his house with one of his victims, raised troubling new questions about what Trump may have known
Reported by CBS News, France24, BBC World and others

items.title: What we learned from newly released Jeffrey Epstein emails
items.standfirst: Democrats on the House Oversight Committee earlier this week released a tranche of emails from convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Barry Levine, a journalist who has covered Epstein for years, joins "The Takeout" to break down what stood out.
items.content: Democrats on the House Oversight Committee earlier this week released a tranche of emails from convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Barry Levine, a journalist who has covered Epstein for years, joins "The Takeout" to break down what stood out.

items.title: Jeffrey Epstein survivor Annie Farmer on files release: "For us, it is not political"
items.standfirst: The House is expected to vote next week on releasing files related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Survivor Annie Farmer joins "The Takeout" to discuss her push for disclosure.
items.content: The House is expected to vote next week on releasing files related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Survivor Annie Farmer joins "The Takeout" to discuss her push for disclosure.

items.title: House to vote as early as next week on Epstein files release
items.standfirst: House Speaker Mike Johnson says the House will vote on a discharge petition next week to seek the release of files related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. CBS News senior White House correspondent Weijia Jiang has the latest on the Trump administration's response.
items.content: House Speaker Mike Johnson says the House will vote on a discharge petition next week to seek the release of files related to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. CBS News senior White House correspondent Weijia Jiang has the latest on the Trump administration's response.

items.title: In newly released emails, Epstein suggests Donald Trump knew of 'about the girls'
items.standfirst: Jeffrey Epstein suggested Donald Trump knew about his abuse and “spent hours” with a victim at his home, according to emails released by Democrats on Wednesday, raising fresh questions for the US president. Trump has denied any knowledge of Epstein’s sex-trafficking crimes and accused Democrats of political deflection.
items.content: Jeffrey Epstein suggested Donald Trump knew about his abuse and “spent hours” with a victim at his home, according to emails released by Democrats on Wednesday, raising fresh questions for the US president. Trump has denied any knowledge of Epstein’s sex-trafficking crimes and accused Democrats of political deflection.

items.title: House prepares to vote on releasing Epstein files
items.standfirst: The US House of Representative will vote next week on whether to require the Justice Department to publish all of its unclassified files on sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Democrats said the emails, including one in which Epstein said Trump spent hours at his house with one of his victims, raised troubling new questions about what Trump may have known. FRANCE 24's Emerald Maxwell and Fraser Jackson report.
items.content: The US House of Representative will vote next week on whether to require the Justice Department to publish all of its unclassified files on sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Democrats said the emails, including one in which Epstein said Trump spent hours at his house with one of his victims, raised troubling new questions about what Trump may have known. FRANCE 24's Emerald Maxwell and Fraser Jackson report.

items.title: What we know about new Epstein emails that mention Trump
items.standfirst: In emails released by Democrats, Epstein says Trump "knew about the girls". The White House says they are an attempt to "smear" the president.
items.content: In emails released by Democrats, Epstein says Trump "knew about the girls". The White House says they are an attempt to "smear" the president.

clusters.title: Watch: Blue Origin sends satellites to Mars in historic launch

items.content: Blue Origin, owned by Jeff Bezos, plans to challenge SpaceX with the powerful, partially reusable New Glenn rocket.

items.title: Blue Origin sticks first New Glenn rocket landing and launches NASA spacecraft
items.standfirst: It's an impressive accomplishment for the new mega-rocket launch system, and paves the way for the company to start re-using the boosters in commercial missions.
items.content: It's an impressive accomplishment for the new mega-rocket launch system, and paves the way for the company to start re-using the boosters in commercial missions.

items.title: Bezos' Blue Origin Successfully Lands Booster After Rocket Launch
items.standfirst: Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin launched its New Glenn rocket from Florida into space and successfully landed its first-stage booster rocket on a barge in the Atlantic Ocean. It's a historic mission. The rocket will send two spacecraft on a trajectory toward Mars. The booster landing is key to Blue Origin’s goal of making New Glenn partially reusable. Recovered boosters would be recycled for multiple launches. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin launched its New Glenn rocket from Florida into space and successfully landed its first-stage booster rocket on a barge in the Atlantic Ocean. It's a historic mission. The rocket will send two spacecraft on a trajectory toward Mars. The booster landing is key to Blue Origin’s goal of making New Glenn partially reusable. Recovered boosters would be recycled for multiple launches. (Source: Bloomberg)

clusters.title: REPLAY: Ten years on from the November Paris terror attacks, France honours the victims
clusters.neutral_headline: France Commemorates Paris Terror Attack Anniversary
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, NPR News, Guardian World and others

items.title: REPLAY: Ten years on from the November Paris terror attacks, France honours the victims
items.standfirst: France paid an emotional tribute on Thursday to the 132 people killed 10 years ago during coordinated attacks by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers targeting cafes, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall in Paris. Watch a replay of the full ceremony.
items.content: France paid an emotional tribute on Thursday to the 132 people killed 10 years ago during coordinated attacks by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers targeting cafes, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall in Paris. Watch a replay of the full ceremony.

items.title: How has Paris changed since the 2015 terror attacks?
items.standfirst: Ten years ago, France's deadliest attacks since World War II hit Paris, killing 132 people and wounding at least 350. Clovis Casali, a FRANCE 24 Reporter, was present at one of the bars.
items.content: Ten years ago, France's deadliest attacks since World War II hit Paris, killing 132 people and wounding at least 350. Clovis Casali, a FRANCE 24 Reporter, was present at one of the bars.

items.title: A decade after the Bataclan attacks, France is still grappling with how to remember
items.standfirst: In the 2015 attacks, 130 people were killed, including at the Bataclan concert hall. France is still wrestling with how to remember the deadliest attack on its soil in modern history and how to live with it.
items.content: In the 2015 attacks, 130 people were killed, including at the Bataclan concert hall. France is still wrestling with how to remember the deadliest attack on its soil in modern history and how to live with it.(Image credit: Ludovic Marin)

items.title: ‘The pain remains’: France remembers victims of 2015 Paris attacks
items.standfirst: Bells ring out across French capital marking 10th anniversary of country’s deadliest peacetime attackParis attacks anniversary – in picturesFrance has paid tribute to the 130 people killed 10 years ago by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers who targeted a stadium, bars, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall in the country’s deadliest peacetime attack.“The pain remains,” Emmanuel Macron wrote on social media on Thursday as he visited each of the sites that were attacked. Bells rang out across the city as a remembrance ceremony began at a memorial garden in central Paris attended by relatives and survivors. Continue reading...
items.content: Bells ring out across French capital marking 10th anniversary of country’s deadliest peacetime attackParis attacks anniversary – in picturesFrance has paid tribute to the 130 people killed 10 years ago by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers who targeted a stadium, bars, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall in the country’s deadliest peacetime attack.“The pain remains,” Emmanuel Macron wrote on social media on Thursday as he visited each of the sites that were attacked. Bells rang out across the city as a remembrance ceremony began at a memorial garden in central Paris attended by relatives and survivors. Continue reading...

items.title: Survivors' choir sings Rival Sons at 2015 Paris attacks commemoration ceremony
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2025, terrorist attacks conducted in Paris by Islamic State fighters killed 132 people. One year on, a choir made up of survivors and victims's relatives sang 'Shooting Stars' by Rival Sons at the commemoration ceremony.
items.content: On November 13, 2025, terrorist attacks conducted in Paris by Islamic State fighters killed 132 people. One year on, a choir made up of survivors and victims's relatives sang 'Shooting Stars' by Rival Sons at the commemoration ceremony.

items.title: France marks 10 years since Paris attacks upended country
items.standfirst: Parisians marked ten years since the deadly November 2015 attacks that upended French society.
items.content: Parisians marked ten years since the deadly November 2015 attacks that upended French society.

items.title: French national anthem, 'La Marseillaise', at 2015 terror attacks commemoration ceremony
items.standfirst: France marks ten years since harrowing Paris terror attacks. French singer Axelle Saint-Cirel sang the French anthem, La Marseillaise, at the ceremony commemorating the attacks.
items.content: France marks ten years since harrowing Paris terror attacks. French singer Axelle Saint-Cirel sang the French anthem, La Marseillaise, at the ceremony commemorating the attacks.

items.title: President Emmanuel Macron gives speech at ceremony commemorating 2015 Paris terror attacks
items.standfirst: On Thursday, during the ceremony commemorating the attacks of November 13, 2015, Emmanuel Macron described the “senseless, unjust, unbearable” pain of the victims. Ten years ago to the day, Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers targeted cafes, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall, killing 132 people.
items.content: On Thursday, during the ceremony commemorating the attacks of November 13, 2015, Emmanuel Macron described the “senseless, unjust, unbearable” pain of the victims. Ten years ago to the day, Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers targeted cafes, restaurants and the Bataclan concert hall, killing 132 people.

items.title: Paris Remembers: 2015 terror attacks commemoration ceremony opens with music
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. A year on, a commemoration ceremony took place to pay homage to the victims, with music and dance performances.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. A year on, a commemoration ceremony took place to pay homage to the victims, with music and dance performances.

items.title: Survivors of 2015 Paris terror attacks perform "You will never walk alone"
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. Ten years on, a choir made up of survivors and relatives of people who died performed "You will never walk alone" at a commemoration ceremony.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks turned Paris into a theater of blood and calamity, with gunfire on café terraces, explosions by a stadium and a nighttime massacre at the Bataclan concert hall, leaving 132 people dead and at least 350 injured. Ten years on, a choir made up of survivors and relatives of people who died performed "You will never walk alone" at a commemoration ceremony.

items.title: 'Whoever attacks Paris attacks all of humanity': Ten years on, France commemorates terror attacks
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks in Paris killed 132 people, including two survivors who later died by suicide, and wounded at least 350. Many families now measure time as “before” and “after.” Ten years on, the mayor of Paris, Anne Hidalgo, gave a speech at the ceremony commemorating the victims of the attack.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, coordinated terrorist attacks in Paris killed 132 people, including two survivors who later died by suicide, and wounded at least 350. Many families now measure time as “before” and “after.” Ten years on, the mayor of Paris, Anne Hidalgo, gave a speech at the ceremony commemorating the victims of the attack.

items.title: Ten years after the Paris 2015 terror attacks, heroes read out the names of victims
items.standfirst: Ten years ago, 132 people were killed by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers in the deadliest attack in France's modern history. Ten years later to the day, heroes read out the names of the 132 victims who died that horrific evening, during a commemoration ceremony.
items.content: Ten years ago, 132 people were killed by Islamic State gunmen and suicide bombers in the deadliest attack in France's modern history. Ten years later to the day, heroes read out the names of the 132 victims who died that horrific evening, during a commemoration ceremony.

items.title: Dancers perform emotional choreography at 2015 Paris terror attack commemoration
items.standfirst: France marks a decade since suffering its deadliest terrorist attack in modern history. Ten years on, a commemoration ceremony took place in Paris to pay tribute the victims, which included dancers perfoming an emotional choreography.
items.content: France marks a decade since suffering its deadliest terrorist attack in modern history. Ten years on, a commemoration ceremony took place in Paris to pay tribute the victims, which included dancers perfoming an emotional choreography.

items.title: 'Life is stronger than death': France remembers its victims, ten years after the 2015 terror attacks
items.standfirst: On November 13, 2015, France experienced its deadliest attacks on French soil since World War Two, scarring the national psyche and prompting emergency security measures, many of which are now embedded in law. Ten years on, Philippe Duperron, president of the Victims association "13onze15" gave an opening speech at the ceremony commemorating the attacks.
items.content: On November 13, 2015, France experienced its deadliest attacks on French soil since World War Two, scarring the national psyche and prompting emergency security measures, many of which are now embedded in law. Ten years on, Philippe Duperron, president of the Victims association "13onze15" gave an opening speech at the ceremony commemorating the attacks.

items.title: France remembers Bataclan attacks but knows enemy has not gone away
items.standfirst: As France marks 10 years since the Paris attacks, an ex-girlfriend of a jihadist survivor is arrested for an alleged plot of her own.
items.content: As France marks 10 years since the Paris attacks, an ex-girlfriend of a jihadist survivor is arrested for an alleged plot of her own.

ai_summary: France commemorated the tenth anniversary of the 2015 Paris attacks.
The attacks killed 132 people in Paris ten years ago.
A memorial ceremony was held in central Paris.
Survivors and relatives attended the commemoration.
A choir sang at the commemoration ceremony.

items.standfirst: Israeli President Isaac Herzog this week condemned the latest outbreak of settler-instigated violence against Palestinians in the West Bank, decrying a recent arson attack near the city of Tulkarm as “shocking and serious” in some of his most high-profile public statements on the longstanding…

items.title: Israeli president condemns ‘serious’ attack by settlers on West Bank villages
items.standfirst: Isaac Herzog makes rare statement on often-ignored violence as settlers injure Palestinians and attack soldiersDozens of masked Israeli settlers attacked Palestinian villages in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday, injuring four Palestinians and attacking Israeli soldiers in the latest incident of rising settler violence.The settlers attacked the Palestinian villages of Beit Lid and Deir Sharaf, setting vehicles on fire and damaging property belonging to a Bedouin community, with charred remains of cars left behind the next day. Continue reading...

items.title: Masked Israeli settlers attack Palestinian villages and IDF soldiers in the West Bank
items.standfirst: Settlers attacked Palestinians and set fire to property in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday before clashing with soldiers sent to break up their rampage.
items.content: Settlers attacked Palestinians and set fire to property in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday before clashing with soldiers sent to break up their rampage.

ai_summary: Israeli settlers attacked a mosque in the West Bank.
The attack drew international condemnation.
Israeli President Herzog condemned the settler violence.
Settlers injured Palestinians and attacked Israeli soldiers.
The UN reports settler violence is at a record high.

items.title: Air traffic controllers promised fast shutdown pay, but they've been told that before
items.standfirst: The Transportation Secretary says air traffic controllers will be paid promptly as the government reopens. But after the last shutdown, in 2019, some controllers sued to get paid in full for overtime.

clusters.title: Donald Trump pardons UK billionaire and former Tottenham owner Joe Lewis
clusters.neutral_headline: Donald Trump Pardons Joe Lewis
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, BBC Top Stories

items.title: Donald Trump pardons UK billionaire and former Tottenham owner Joe Lewis
items.standfirst: Lewis was fined $5m and given three years probation by New York judge over ‘brazen’ insider trading schemeJoe Lewis, the British billionaire and former owner of Tottenham Hotspur FC, has been pardoned by Donald Trump over a 2024 conviction for his part in a “brazen” insider trading scheme.Lewis, 88, was fined $5m (£3.8m) and given three years probation by a New York judge last year but was spared jail time after pleading guilty to involvement in a plan that prosecutors said was designed to enrich his friends, lovers and employees. Continue reading...
items.content: Lewis was fined $5m and given three years probation by New York judge over ‘brazen’ insider trading schemeJoe Lewis, the British billionaire and former owner of Tottenham Hotspur FC, has been pardoned by Donald Trump over a 2024 conviction for his part in a “brazen” insider trading scheme.Lewis, 88, was fined $5m (£3.8m) and given three years probation by a New York judge last year but was spared jail time after pleading guilty to involvement in a plan that prosecutors said was designed to enrich his friends, lovers and employees. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Trump administration targets European antifa groups as ‘global terrorists’
clusters.neutral_headline: US Designates European Antifa Groups as Terrorist Threats
bullet_summary: Reported by Al Jazeera, Guardian World

items.title: Trump administration targets European antifa groups as ‘global terrorists’
items.standfirst: US State Department labelled four groups, from Germany, Greece and Italy, as 'specially designated global terrorists'.
items.content: US State Department labelled four groups, from Germany, Greece and Italy, as 'specially designated global terrorists'.

items.title: US designates four European anti-fascist groups as terrorist threats
items.standfirst: State department claims groups in Germany, Italy and Greece ‘conspiring to undermine foundations of western civilization’The US state department has announced that it will designate four European self-described anti-fascist groups as Foreign Terrorist Organisations, as the Trump administration broadens its campaign against what it portrays as an international wave of leftist violence.In a public statement on Thursday, the state department said it would designate Antifa Ost in Germany, the Italy-based International Revolutionary Front, and two organisations in Greece – Armed Proletarian Justice and Revolutionary Class Self Defense – as “Specially Designated Global Terrorists … conspiring to undermine the foundations of Western Civilization through their brutal attacks”. Continue reading...
items.content: State department claims groups in Germany, Italy and Greece ‘conspiring to undermine foundations of western civilization’The US state department has announced that it will designate four European self-described anti-fascist groups as Foreign Terrorist Organisations, as the Trump administration broadens its campaign against what it portrays as an international wave of leftist violence.In a public statement on Thursday, the state department said it would designate Antifa Ost in Germany, the Italy-based International Revolutionary Front, and two organisations in Greece – Armed Proletarian Justice and Revolutionary Class Self Defense – as “Specially Designated Global Terrorists … conspiring to undermine the foundations of Western Civilization through their brutal attacks”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The US State Department labeled four groups as global terrorists.
These groups are from Germany, Greece, and Italy.
The State Department is broadening its campaign.
The groups are described as anti-fascist.
The US claims the groups undermine Western civilization.

items.title: Trump writes to Israeli president calling for Netanyahu pardon
items.standfirst: Isaac Herzog can pardon convicted criminals in some circumstances, but cases against Israeli PM are ongoingDonald Trump has repeated a request to Israel’s president, Isaac Herzog, for a pardon for Benjamin Netanyahu, who is on trial in three separate corruption cases.The Israeli prime minister has repeatedly denied any wrongdoing in the ongoing court cases. No rulings have been delivered, and his supporters have dismissed the trials as politically motivated. Continue reading...
